citation.article-title: Pseudomonas caeni sp. nov., a denitrifying bacterium isolated from the sludge of an anaerobic ammonium-oxidizing bioreactor
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pseudomonas caeni sp. nov.
Pseudomonas caeni (cae′ni. L. gen. neut. n. caeni of sludge).
Cells are Gram-negative, aerobic, non-spore-forming rods approximately 0.4–0.7×1.0–2.0 μm in size.
Cells are motile by means of a polar flagellum (see Supplementary Fig. S1 in IJSEM Online).
Colonies on TSA are translucent, pale yellow, circular and usually 1–2 mm in diameter after 2 days incubation at 30 °C.
Cells do not produce fluorescent pigment on King's B media.
Growth occurs at 4–37 °C (optimum, 30 °C), but not at 42 °C.
Growth occurs in the presence of 0–3 % (w/v) NaCl (optimum, 0.5–1 %), but not in the presence of 5 % (w/v) NaCl.

Positive for esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8) and leucine arylamidase, but negative for activities of urease, α-glucosidase, β-glucosidase, lipase (C14), arginine dihydrolase, α-chymotrypsin, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, alkaline phosphatase, acid phosphatase, valine arylamidase, cystine arylamidase, β-glucuronidase, α-fucosidase, α-mannosidase and N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase.
Negative for acidification of d-glucose, indole production and hydrolysis of starch, aesculin, gelatin, trypsin and Tween 80.
Nitrate and nitrite are reduced under anaerobic conditions.

Caprate and malate are utilized as sole carbon sources, but the following substrates are not utilized as a sole carbon source: adipate, arabinose, citrate, d-glucose, gluconate, maltose, mannitol, mannose, N-acetylglucosamine or phenylacetate.
The major fatty acids are summed feature 3, C16 : 0 and C18 : 1ω7c, with smaller amounts of C12 : 0, C10 : 0 3-OH, C12 : 0 3-OH and C14 : 0.
The G+C content of the genomic DNA is 50.6±0.5 mol%.
The type strain, HY-14T (=KCTC 22292T=CCTCC AB208156T) and an additional strain, HY-24 (=KCTC 22293=CCTCC AB208157), were isolated from the sludge of an anaerobic ammonium-oxidizing bioreactor.
